THE NEW YORK TIMES MAGAZINE, DECEMBER 11, 1927
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
NEW HONOR FOR A HEROIC ARMY DOCTOR

Major Reed's Birthplace Is Made a National Monument
In Recognition of His Conquest of Yellow Fever

It is dramatically fitting that in
the year that the last traces of
one of the great scourges of
mankind are being driven from
the face of the earth the birth-
place of the man who gave that
boon to mankind is to be made into
a national memorial in his honor.

Wars that kill men are at worst
merely periodic; the vaster conflict
to save their lives goes on forever
against foemen often unknown. De-
cisive victories on the frontiers of
medicine are more rare than on the
field of battle. But when they are
won they not only save thousands
from suffering and death; they in-
sure the millions yet unborn as
well. During the heat of a Cuban
Summer Dr. Walter Reed, a sur-
geon major in the United States
Army who had been detailed to
study in Havana a disease that had
baffled medical men for more than
three centuries, won such a victory
over the yellow fever scourge.

That was more than twenty-five
years ago. It would be pleasant to
record that at the time the nation
honored him as it would a general
victorious in battle, but that would
hardly be accurate. He was mod-
erately praised in the short time
that he was yet to live and then
he went on to whatever immortal-
ity this world gives its doctors. To-
day his name is largely associated
in the public mind with the vet-
erans' hospital at Washington that
bears his name. Books have been
devoted to his achievement, ac-
knowledgments appear in works of
reference. But the details of that
epochal accomplishment in Havana
which has made possible the eradi-
cation of yellow fever in tropical
countries, where thousands of peo-
ple died from the disease every
year, are a trifle misty in the gen-
eral recollection. So many more
spectacular heroes have had their
brief hours since then.

THE little house where Reed lived
at Belroi, in Gloucester County,
Va., will make a peculiarly ap-
propriate national memorial to him.
A structure that is little more than a
cabin, wholly unpretentious, stands
not far from the Tidewater Trail
between Washington and Norfolk.
It was originally built for the over-
seer of a plantation. There, the
pilgrim coming to honor a great
man and the casual tourist passing
will be told Walter Reed, the son
of a Methodist country minister,
was born in 1851.

It was in the blazing June of
1900 that the curtain went up on
the main drama of Walter Reed's
life. Already a brilliant bacteriolo-
gist. Curator of the Army Museum
and its laboratory in Washington,
he had two years before been as-
signed to study the causes of the
typhoid fever outbreaks among
troops collected for the Spanish-
American War and now he was or-
dered to the commission in Havana
that was investigating yellow fever,
the plague of the southern hemi-
sphere.

Early practice when a lieutenant
assistant surgeon on duty at
isolated garrisons in the Far West,
where settlers came to the post
with all the fundamental human
ills, had taught him to face any
emergency. Technical preparation
at the University of Virginia and
at Bellevue Hospital Medical Col-
lege in New York had been supple-
mented by work in the laboratories
at Johns Hopkins in the great day
of Professor William Welch. That
work had stamped him as a master
in medical research. Here was a
St. George worthy to kill the great
yellow dragon--if it could be killed.

The record of history was against
him. The first lair of the dragon
had been placed in Mexico among
the Aztecs, and it had been placed
in Africa among the negroes who
were brought over as slaves of the
Spaniards who swarmed after Cor-
tez. Whatever its origin, “yellow
jack” had killed both in vast num-
bers and remained to prey the
length and breadth of the New
World, destroying one of Napo-
leon's expeditionary forces to Haiti
in 1800, wiping out a village here
and a boat's crew there.

Traveling northward, it had killed
about 100,000 Americans before the
Republic was fairly established,
reaching as far north as New York,
where people fled in panic. The
dragon had stretched its yellow
coils across the Isthmus of Panama
when the French were trying to
dig a canal there, and those who

lived sailed home. Now it was at-
tacking American soldiers who
were setting up the Cuban repub-
lic. One-third of General Wood's
own staff had died. More insoluble
than ever, the ghastly riddle of the
fever defied the world.

Then Major Reed took a hand.
He had been in pest holes before,
he had grown up during the Civil
War, and neither war nor pestilence
could dismay him. He walked
through the sepulchral halls where
young soldiers who had come
through battles were dying help-
lessly of fever, and he investigated
the sanitary state of the old Span-
ish town. General Gorgas, who was
to achieve his own fame in Pan-
ama, was there, too. He was scrub-
bing the accumulated filth of cen-
turies from Havana, but that had
not reduced yellow fever. All the
usual experiments were made by
the commission, just as they had
been made year after year by ear-
nest physicians who published large,
elaborately documented reports that,
however, did not indicate causes.
The yellow dragon went on his
lethal way. Presently two contribu-
tions to the inquiry began to inter-
est Major Reed. One came from
Mississippi, the other originated
there in Cuba. Another army sur-
geon. Henry R. Carter, had dis-
covered that, in the case of an in-
fected house, people who went there
immediately after some one had
had yellow fever in it did not catch
the disease. The other theory was
put forth by Dr. Carlos J. Finlay of
Havana. Dr. Finlay's friends had
taken him seriously on practically
everything until he began to dis-
cuss his “hallucination” about mos-
quitos carrying yellow fever. Though
he had tried for years, he had never
been able to show a case. He merely
thought mosquitos carried it.

Major Reed's experiments now
took a new direction. He was going
to leave no stone unturned, and he
was going to give the theories of
these two men a thorough trial. It
was destined to be more thorough
than any one expected when it be-
gan; it was to lead to experiment
with human beings, a thing un-
dreamed of, before the genius of
the quiet Virginian had arrived at
ultimate conclusions--and triumph.
First Finlay's mosquitos, which he
coddled as household pets, were to
be allowed to bite men sick unto
death with yellow fever, and then
they were to be transferred to the
arms of healthy men. Who were
those men to be?

Major Reed, intent upon science,
wanted very much to be one. But
the rest of the investigating com-
mission would not allow that, be-
cause if he should die the investi-
gation would end. Then Reed was
ordered to Washington on official
business. And while he was away
Dr. Jesse Lazear, another member
of the commission, one day took a
mosquito that had been in a fever
ward and allowed it to bite him.
The human experiment was on.
But nothing happened. What was
wrong? Experimenters had failed
to take into account the fact that
Dr. Carter had contributed: it takes
about a week or ten days the pe-
riod of mosquito incubation after
the infection--for the mosquito to
become a carrier of the disease.

Then the fates dealt a double
blow. For Dr. Carroll, of the com-
mission, who risked the chance of
death by making himself the sub-
ject of the next experiment, caught
the disease, and while he was lying
at death's door Dr. Lazear, who had
once survived the ordeal, was bit-
ten accidentally by a free mosquito
flying about the room and died.
But no one could prove the mos-
quito was infected. A few days
later Major Reed returned from
Washington.

Now the supreme decision must
be made. One man had died gal-
lantly in pursuit of a theory that
was far from having been tested.
Should the experiments continue,
with such risks in the balance?
Reed looked at the rows of dying
men who were following thousands
of others into the shades because
there was no way of halting the
invasion of “yellow jack.” The ex-
periments went on.

REED now announced that vol-
unteers were wanted. Pri-
vate John R. Kissinger and a
civilian clerk. John J. Moran, both
from Ohio, came forward. Dr.
Reed candidly explained the risk
they ran--certain disease, almost
certain death, for 85 out of 100
were dying--and that the most they
could hope for was a small Govern-
ment pension for reward. At that
they made their one stipulation--
that they should receive no reward
at all. Reed rose from his chair.
“Gentlemen, I salute you!” he said.

So a small camp of death was es-
tablished, and named for Lazear.
There the two men, who were to
spend most of the rest of their days
forgotten, endured the stings of
mosquitos that had bitten others in
the last stages of a dreaded malady.
Three days after he had been bit-
ten, Kissinger became violently ill.
The experiment was a success. And
he lived to tell the tale. Broken in
body, he is still alive on a farm
that grateful people gave him twen-
ty-seven years later. Moran allowed
himself to be bitten, and lived.

Victory was in sight--but it could
not be proclaimed until every possi-
bility had been tested. That meant
that the old theories of contagion
and contamination must also be
thoroughly tried. So through the
horrors of long nights volunteers
lay in the blankets and clothing of
other men who had died of yellow
fever, specially brought to Camp
Lazear for them while Reed, bear-
ing full responsibility, sleepless and
torn with anxiety, watched the ex-
periments. And because the win-
dows were screened the volunteers
did not fall prey to the yellow
dragon whose emissary of death
was at last proved to be the
Stegomyia mosquito.

One of the great lasting conquests
in medicine had been achieved.
Walter Reed had found the way to
save the lives of millions of people.
He had triumphed over an enemy
centuries old. He had made it
possible for white men to go into
parts of the tropics where they
could not have lived before, and ac-
complish the work of civilization.
Had his discovery been made sooner
France might have accomplished
the building of the Panama Canal.

Now the great work of making
the tropics healthful began there in
Havana, when Gorgas, under Reed's
directions, began to destroy the
breeding places of the Stegomyia.
He was to carry on that work in
Panama with shining success, and
others have carried it to the ends
of the earth.

After Gorgas had cleaned up the
Canal Zone and enabled the Ameri-
can canal builders to work without
fear of fever, the task of eliminat-
ing the scourge from ‘Central and
South America was taken up. Cities

and ports that had been pest-holes
for centuries were soon freed of the
scourge and in our country New
Orleans was able to write the end
of an ugly chapter in her history.
Today yellow fever is making its
last stand in Africa.

Stegomyia, with her beautifully
marked wings, is still carrying the
disease in certain parts of the Gold
Coast, and at Lagos, in Nigeria, the
Rockefeller Foundation has estab-
lished a fever-fighting field station.
Set high above the ground on con-
crete pillars are the buildings where
the American scientists live. There
is an office, a laboratory, two dor-
mitories and a staff house. And it
is there, in the heart of darkness,
that the final chapter is being writ-
ten for the great book of progress
in the preservation of human life
that Walter Reed began in Cuba.

Twenty-five years ago, when Sur-
geon Major Reed returned to the
United States and Harvard and
Michigan bestowed honorary de-
grees upon him, it was said that
his experiments would always “re-
main as models in the annals of
scientific research, both for the ex-
actness with which they were
adapted to the points to be proved
and the precautions taken that no
experiment should be vitiated by
failure to exclude all possible
sources of error.” That is perhaps
the epitaph that he himself would
have liked best, the judgment that
his peers in the austere roll of sci-
entists would pass, coupled with
the words that President Eliot
spoke when he gave him his de-
gree: “He gave to man control
over that dreadful plague, yellow
fever”--the inscription over his
tomb in Arlington.

Reed died of appendicitis in
Washington in 1902. Suitable ma-
terial memorials are slow in com-
ing to him, as they have been to
many others among the great. But
few can have such a memorial as a
universe freed from a scourge. His
last words, as he lay dying at the
moment when the world was be-
ginning to receive the first bene-
fits of his lasting achievement,
were as characteristic as any he
ever uttered.

“I leave so little,” he said. So
little!
